The inmost sphere approaches the simplicitatem medietatis (i.e., the immobility of the central point) and stands in the same relation to the outer spheres as the cardo stands to the inmost. orbium . . . vertentium: genitive depends on intimus . qui: sc. orbis . extra locatorum: sc. orbium . extimus: sc. orbis . quanto . . . tanto: "so far as . . . to the same extent." a puncti media individuitate: "from the indivisibility of a mid-point"; media is a transferred epithet. illi . . . medio: "to that mid-point." simili ratione: up to this point (from ut orbium . . . ) the sentence has been all simile; now the main clause begins. prima mente: i.e., mente divina , but the turn of phrase is very Platonic. vicinius: "more nearly."
Fati: genitive with necessitatem .
uti est: introduces four similes to describe the relation of the fati series mobilis to the providentiae stabilis simplicitas .
in se . . . temperat: "harmonizes to one another." eadem: sc. series . per similes fetuum seminumque . . . progressus: "by similar advances of offspring and seeds."
Haec: sc. series . quae = et haec (sc. conexio ). ipsas: sc. causas .
indeclinabilem: "constant, unvarying." promat: < promo , "bring out, produce." alioquin temere fluituras: "which would otherwise randomly dissipate away." incommutabilitate: "immutability."
vobis . . . minime considerare valentibus: "to you . . . not at all able to consider." suus modus: suus looks ahead to cuncta : "their own limit arranges all things, directing [them] to the good."
causa: "for the sake of . . ." ne . . . improbis: "not even [when done] by the wicked themselves." fiat: "is done." quoquam: "in any direction." deflectat: here intransitive.
tum . . . tum: "now (one one occasion) . . . now (on another occasion)."
ea: demonstrative force emphasized: "with such integrity" (specified by result clause ut . . . sit ). degunt: "live, pass their lives." uti existimant: "just as they judge [they are]."
depugnant: "fight it out."
temperiem: "harmonious balance of the elements," term borrowed consciously from medical usage.
miraculum: see on 4P6.1.
dinoscit = dignoscit , "distinguishes."
specula: "watchtower." unicuique: < unusquisque , "each and every one." accommodat: "furnishes, supplies."
hic: "here." ab sciente: i.e., deo .

perstringam: < perstringo , "graze lightly, touch upon." de hoc quem . . . putas: "of the one you think . . ."; another human being. servantissimum: "most observant," < servans (participle < servo ). omnia: object of scienti . diversum videtur: impersonal; translate, "it seems otherwise."

Lucan, Bellum Civile 1.128; the gods side with Caesar (and give him victory) but Cato (a model of conscience and rectitude) sided with Pompey. B. misses Lucan's irony. familiaris noster: Lucan was reputed a student of Stoicism.
citra spem: "this side of hope," i.e., falling short of what is hoped for.
bene moratus: "well-conducted." animi viribus: cf. English, "strength of character." adversi: partitive genitive with quid .
sapiens dispensatio: sc. dei . laborare: "to struggle" under the burden of adversity.
absolutus: almost the same as perfectus ; cf. 3M9.9. hunc contingi (sc. esse ) . . . nefas: indirect statement with hunc contingi as subject.

quidam me quoque excellentior: source is unknown; perhaps a late theosophic-philosophical text from the Hermetic tradition. *a)ndro\s dh\ i(erou= de/mas ai)qe/res w)|kodo/mhsan : Literally: "The upper-heavens built the body of the holy man," but ai)qe/res are probably the divine element in man and hence emphasizes that some men, beloved of divinity, are immune to ordinary ills.

distribuit: sc. providentia . quosdam . . . remordet: the ellipsis (inserted by Weinberger) marks the lack of an ablative of instrument. The point has been controverted by those who hold that remordet ("causes to worry") can stand with only the accusative object. <sinit> agitari: the insertion of sinit is a conjecture; others emend agitari to agitat . confirment: "make stronger"; subject is inferred from alios .
plus aequo: "more than is appropriate." experimentum sui: "a trial of themselves."

saeculi: "of [this] world." suppliciis inexpugnabiles: "unconquerable by tortures." invictam . . . virtutem: accusative/infinitive in apposition with exemplum . quae: i.e., the various fates described in 35-42. disposite: "methodically." ex eorum bono: virtually, "for their own good."
illud: subject of ducitur ; in apposition with noun clause, quod . . . proveniunt .

eos: sc. improbos . malo: "by their evil"; on the text, cf. Gruber. laeta: opposite of tristia (cf. optata in sec. 43). quid . . . debeant iudicare: indirect question in apposition with argumentum . famulari: see on 4P6.13.

illud . . . dispensari: "this thing is arranged," i.e., "this arrangement is made"; accusative/infinitive. rei familiaris: "private property, wealth." medetur: < medeor , "treat [a disease]," with dative.
Hic: introduces another hypothetical individual. cuius: understand as antecedent a genitive with tristis amissio .

cladem: "ruin, disaster." indigne acta: "unworthily handled." quibusdam permissum (sc. est ) : there is no connective (asyndeton). puniendi ius: "the right to punish," i.e., a civil magistracy. causa: governs objective genitives exercitii and supplicii .
convenire: "to agree, come together."
a semet: "from himself," taken closely with dissentiat . ipsis . . . vitiis: ablative absolute. faciant . . . decernent: sc. viri .
Ex quo: antecedent vague; cf. sec. 47-49.
sibi . . . videntur: "they seem . . . to themselves." rediere = redierunt . dum: causal.
bona: predicative. eis competenter utendo: "by using them [i.e., mala ] suitably." elicit: "lure out, elicit, draw out"; subject is divina vis .

adsignata ordinis ratione: "from its assigned place in that order." licet . . . ordinem: "although into another [order], nevertheless [into] an order." temeritati: "unpredictable, random, disorderly action": dative with liceat .

*a)rgale/on de' me tau=ta qeo\n w(\s pa/nt' a)goreu/ein : Iliad 12.176: "It is burdensome for me to declaim all these things, as if I were a god," where the poet quails at describing the tumult of battle.

Hoc tantum perspexisse: subject of sufficiat . proditor: a later Latin sense: "one who brings forth." quod . . . disponat . . . eliminet: noun clause in apposition with hoc tantum . Classical Latin would prefer accusative/infinitive. idem: modifying deus ; "one and the same." in sui similitudinem: cf. 3M9.8.
quae: i.e., "evil things."
carminis . . . dulcedinem: postponed at 4P6.6. haustum: "something to drink" (with medical overtones still).

div.head: Metrum 6:
div.p: The world is ruled by an ordered plan. The poem has the same meter as 1M5, the same subject (order in the cosmos), the same number of lines, and the same outline: 1M5.1-24 order above 4M6.1-24 1M5.25-48 disorder below 4M6.25-48
Meter: Anapestic dimeter with diaeresis.
Tonantis: "the thunderer," i.e., Jupiter.
pura: ablative.
concitus: < concio , "rouse, provoke."
Phoebes: Greek genitive singular, "of the moon." axem: literally, "axis," i.e., a fixed point of rotation; here, used for the rotation itself.
Ursa: antecedent of quae (line 8) and subject of cupit (line 12); the "great bear" never goes below the horizon for observers in the northern temperate latitudes.
occiduo: literally, "setting," thus "western" (where the sun and stars set). lota: "washed," one way to spell the perfect passive participle < lavo ( lavatum and lautum also occur).
astrigeris . . . exulat oris: "is in exile from the starry shores."
Cf. 2M8.2ff, 3M9.10ff.

pugnantia: i.e., in conflict with the dryness to which they do in fact yield. (This word provides the only dactyl in a fourth foot in any of the four poems with this meter. The foot may in fact be a spondee with -tia pronounced as a single syllable by synaeresis.)
vicibus: "by turns."
pendulus: "hanging, poised"; fire is normally to be found balanced between the air and the ether.
sidant: "settle, subside."
vere: "in spring" (< ver, veris ).
spirat: here, "exhales, emits" with direct object ( odores ).
haec: accusative.
eadem: object of condit and aufert . condit et aufert: both creates (cf. lines 30-31) and takes away (cf. line 33).
obitu . . . supremo: "in the final passing away." orta: "things having arisen," i.e., "whatever has come to be"; object of mergens .
sistit: "causes to stop."
dissaepta: "separated as if by walls."
boni fine: i.e., by having the Good as their common goal.
converso rursus amore: The divine principle sets all things in motion but then in the end draws them back to rest in itself.
causae: dative with refluant . esse: object of dedit ; translate, "being, existence."

div.head: Prosa 7:
div.p: Everything that happens, including 'bad fortune,' is for the good.
Omnem fortunam: supply a verb like vides (sec. 1). qui = quo , "how."
causa: "for the sake of," governing four preceding gerunds. omnis bona: sc. est .
nixa (sc. est ) : < nitor .
inopinabiles: "unthinkable." paulo ante: cf., e.g., 4P4.10. et quidem crebro: "and indeed frequently."
visne . . . accedamus: "do you want us to agree . . .?" The point of view of the vulgus is taken through section 13.
Quae: sc. fortuna .

haec: sc. fortuna . 11. Quid vero: "But what about?" iucunda: sc. fortuna . num: begins question (expecting negative answer) and thus leaves construction of first part of sentence unfinished. verum uti: "but [just] as."
reliqua: sc. fortuna . 13. Immo: "Quite the contrary . . ."
ne . . . confecerimus: clause of fearing or preventing ( vide here means virtually "beware").

evenit: governs accusative/infinitive, omnem . . . esse fortunam . vel sunt: omit this vel in translation. There are three classes to whom all fortune is good: those who have, those who approach, or those who are attaining virtue. By contrast, there is only one group to whom fortune is bad: those abiding in wickedness.
moleste ferre: "to take [it] badly."
quotiens (twice in this sentence) : "as often," hence, "whenever." ut: "just as."
Utrique: "to both," i.e., huic: "to the vir fortis ," and illi: "to the vir sapiens ." materia: governs both gerundive phrases.
Ex quo: "Whence." diffluere . . . emarcescere: "to wallow . . . to dry up"; infinitives of purpose after venistis .
acre: "bravely, ardently," adverb < acer . conseritis: "you join [battle]."
medium . . . occupate: military imagery continues. habet contemptum felicitatis = contemnit felicitatem . (The construction is used to parallel habet praemium .)
situm: sc. est .

div.head: Metrum 7
div.p: Heroic endurance leads to success.
Meter: Sapphic hendecasyllable with caesura after the fifth syllable. The last verse is an adonic ( - u u - -).
bis quinis = decem . operatus: < operor , "work, be occupied"; here, "having waged" (with accusative: late Latin).
Atrides: "son of Atreus," viz. Agamemnon, leader of the Greek expedition against Troy. Phrygiae: i.e., Troy.
In order to placate the goddess Artemis and secure favoring winds for his becalmed fleet on the way to Troy, Agamemnon sacrificed his daughter Iphigenia at Aulis.
exuit patrem: "he put off [the role of] a father."
foederat: "had stained/defiled." sacerdos: "[as a] priest," apposition with ille .
Odysseus's encounter with the Cyclops, Polyphemus.
Ithacus: "from Ithaca."
alvo: "belly."
caeco . . . ore: "blind visage"; causal ablative; Odysseus had put out the Cyclops's only eye. furibundus: sc. Polyphemus .
rependit: "paid back."
celebrant: "make famous."

The twelve labors of Hercules, which won him divine status (lines 30-31), were given in various lists in antiquity; B. gives them in this order: I) taming the Centaurs (line 14), II) despoiling the Nemean lion (15) ( saevo . . . leoni: dative of separation), III) slaughtering the Stymphalian birds (16) ( fixit: "transfixed," i.e., "shot"), IV) stealing the golden apples of the Hesperides (17-18) ( laevam: accusative of respect with gravior , "weighed down in his left hand"), V) chaining the (three-headed) hellhound, Cerberus, and bringing him up to the light of day (19), VI) feeding the stern Thracian Diomedes to his own horses (20-21), VII) killing the Lernaean Hydra [see 4P6.3] (22) ( combusto: "burned up"), VIII) shaming the river god Achelous in defeat, by breaking off his horns (23-24) ( Achelous: scanned short-short-long-short) IX) killing the giant Antaeus (25) ( stravit: < sterno , "throw down, bring low"), X) killing the half-man Cacus who had been plaguing Evander's city ( Aeneid 8.190f), XI) capturing the Erymanthian boar (and bringing it back) (27-28) ( quosque: antecedent is umeros [28]), XII) holding the world on his shoulders √Ñ√Ñ taking Atlas's place) (29-30, foreshadowed in line 27) ( inreflexo: "unbent").
pretium: governs genitive, ultimi . . . laboris .
caelum: in apposition with pretium .
celsa . . . via: probably the Milky Way.
terga nudatis: "bare your back," as you flee.

div.head: Prosa 1:
div.p: B. insists that P. explain the nature of chance (i.e., casus ); she denies that such a thing exists.
tractanda: < tracto , "handle, treat." expedienda: < expedio , "extricate, disentangle [from confusion]."
dudum . . . dixisti: 4P6.2-4. quaestionem . . . esse: accusative/infinitive in apposition with quod : "what you said, namely that . . ." re: here, "in reality."
an . . . arbitrere (= arbitreris ) : indirect question. esse . . . et quidnam esse casum: indirect statement: "[that] chance exists and what it is."
patriam: accusative of place to which.

cognitu: ablative supine < cognosco . aversa: probably adjective: "contrary, in the wrong direction," with preposition a . ne . . . possis: clause of fearing after verendum est ("it is to be feared"). emetiendum: "traversing" (gerundive of purpose).
loco: here, "opportunity, facility"; a dative of purpose. fuerit: future perfect. ea: object of agnoscere ("to understand").
omne: "every." nihil: subject of ambigatur . de sequentibus: "concerning the consequences [of your argument]." ambigatur: potential subjunctive.

Morem . . . geram: < morem gero , "oblige, humor," with dative. temerario: here, "accidental." praeter subiectae rei significationem: "without signification of [any] subject"; i.e., casus is a word referring to no reality. Praeter regularly means "without" in later Latin. quis . . . ullus: a pleonastic (redundant) later Latin combination; modifies locus . Translate: "what place . . . ?" cohercente . . . deo: ablative absolute.

veterum: e.g., Parmenides (cf. on 1P1.10). refragatus est: < refragor , "oppose, thwart," with dative. id: the principle nihil ex nihilo existere , taken up by hoc below. illi: sc. veteres . de operante principio: "concerning the first mover," i.e., God. materiali subiecto: "matter subject [to the first mover]." omnium de natura rationum: "of all reasoning about nature."
possibile est: governs the accusative/infinitive, casum . . . esse . qualem: antecedent is huius modi in the previous line. paulo ante: 5P1.8.
iure: "by rights, justly." lateat: "escape the notice of," here with accusative vulgus .
Aristoteles . . . in Physicis: Aristotle, Physics 2.4-5; more closely parallel is Metaphysics 1025a14ff. propinqua: with genitive.

gratia: with genitive cuiuspiam rei . aliudque: take closely with quam ("than") quod intendebatur . obtingit: "happens, befalls." ut si: introducing a hypothetical example. defossi: < defodio , "dig up."
fortuito: adverb, "by chance." operatus: sc. esse .
eo loci: "in that place"; loci is partitive genitive.
compendii: "profit." quod: sc. compendium . obviis sibi: "encountering each other." gerentis: "of the one carrying out [the deed]."
ut: introducing purpose clause after intendit . quo: sc. loco . hunc fodisse: accusative/infinitive with convenit and concurrit .
in his: "in these matters." ob aliquid: "for some purpose."
suis: "their own"; refers to cuncta .

div.head: Metrum 1:
div.p: Apparent chance is subject to the laws of causation.
Meter: Elegiac couplets. See on 1M1.

The Tigris and Euphrates rivers arise from a single source (this was a common belief in antiquity); there is an order in nature that keeps them from joining again (an event whose results would be chaotic). (For the phenomenon in lines 1-2 cf. English "Parthian shot.") Rupis: genitive singular. Achaemeniae: "Persian," (Achaemenes was the first Persian king). versa: accusative modifying spicula .
pugna fugax = pugnatores fugaces .
se . . . resolvunt: "free themselves, get loose."
abiunctis . . . aquis: ablative absolute.
confluat: sc. id (explained by the quod -relative clause that follows.) alterni: "of each," the Tigris and the Euphrates. quod: object of trahit .
convenient: future indicative in a mixed conditional. vulsi: participle < vello , "tear up, uproot."
modos: here (often in later Latin), "appearances."
quos . . . vagos . . . casus: object of regit . Quos is connecting relative ("and these").
terrae declivia (< declive , "slope, incline") . . . gurgitis et . . . ordo: compound subject of regit (singular by agreement with the nearest element of the subject).
permissis . . . habenis: ablative absolute, "with the reins allowed [to slip], unchecked." fluitare: "to move unsteadily, wobble."
ipsa: sc. fors .

div.head: Prosa 2:
div.p: P. asserts the existence of human freedom of will even under the reign of divine providence.
haerentium sibi: "closely attached to each other." arbitrii: "of choice." Where we speak of "free will," Latin writers are more inclined to speak of "free choice of [i.e., exercised by] the will."
fuerit: potential subjunctive, "would there be." quin: "without"; with subjunctive after a negative main clause. eidem: dative with adsit .
quod: subject of potest ; antecedent of id in next clause. uti: < utor . se: refers to the subject of the main clause.
substantiis: "entities, natures." optatorum: genitive with efficax ; see on 4P4.11. praesto est: "is at hand."

liberiores quidem: contrasts with minus [sc. liberas ] vero to follow. speculatione: "contemplation." dilabuntur: "slip away, disperse." corpora: these bodies are a mid-point between pure spirit and terreni artus ; it was common Neoplatonic doctrine that spirit and matter could not interact directly without some such intermediary. minusque etiam: "and still less." colligantur: "gathered [and hemmed in] by."
deditae: sc. animae ; "given over [to]," with dative. rationis propriae: objective genitive with possessione .
quibus: dative governed by gerunds that follow.
Quae . . . cuncta: object of prospiciens . ab aeterno: "from all eternity."

div.head: Metrum 2:
div.p: The creator sees and hears all things everywhere.
Meter: Dactylic tetrameter catalectic. Since dactylic lines of fewer than six feet normally end in - u u , the ending - - is catalectic.

Iliad 3.277 (of the sun), modified slightly to fit the syntax: after canit (verse 3) Phoebum is the subject accusative and e)fora=n and e)pakou/ein are the infinitives: "Homer sings that Phoebus . . . 'sees all and hears all."'
melliflui oris: genitive of description.
intima viscera terrae . . . aut pelagi: object of perrumpere . qui: sc. Phoebus .
Past, present, and future.
solus . . . solem: note word-play.

div.head: Prosa 3:
div.p: B. sketches the problems raised by the apparent conflict between divine foreknowledge and human freedom.
quibus perturbere (= perturberis ) : indirect question.
praenoscere . . . esse: the infinitives with their accusative subjects are the compound subject for videtur .
falli: < fallo , "deceive." providentia: ablative, with word-play.
ab aeterno: cf. 5P2.11. nescia falli: "which does not know [how] to be deceived"; modifies providentia .
si aliorsum: "if otherwise." detorqueri: in a "middle" sense, "to twist away." valent: sc. voluntates (sec. 5).
quidam: Many ancient writers, pagan and Christian, suggested the argument Boethius now rejects.
ideo: "for this reason." necessarium hoc: "this necessity." The gist of this proposal is that providence, not the foreseen act, is bound by necessity.

esse . . . esse: infinitives in indirect discourse (continued after aiunt [sec. 8]). contingere . . . provideri: infinitives governed by necesse esse . quasi vero . . . laboretur: "as if indeed one were laboring [to find out] . . ."; with indirect question, quae . . . sit . praescientiane . . . providentiae: in apposition with causa . illud: explained by the acusative/infinitive, necessarium esse eventum .
A hypothetical example. atque e converso rursus: "and again on the other hand." quoniam: here, "that," introducing indirect statement after opinio . This construction is common in later Latin.
quoniam: here, twice, "because, for the reason that" (explaining idcirco in previous line). praecessit: "preceded," (subject is accusative/infinitive, quempiam sedere ).

Similia . . . ratiocinari patet: "it is possible to reason out similar things," i.e., "to reason similarly." idcirco . . . ideo: "for this reason . . . for that reason." provisa This second occurrence is omitted by some manuscripts and editors. quod: "which," antecedent is the whole preceding clause. perimendam: gerundive of purpose < perimo , "kill, destroy."
praeposterum: "preposterous," in its root sense of "out-of-order, confused." ut . . . eventus . . . dicatur: noun clause, subject of praeposterum est . praescientiae: genitive governed by causa .
arbitrari: governs the accusative/infinitive deum futura . . . providere . quae . . . acciderunt: subject of esse .
Ad haec: "[in addition] to this"; introduces further corroboration, in the simile, sicuti . . . ita . . . .
aliorsum atque: "otherwise than."
qui = quo , "how."
impermixta: "un-mixed."
quod: "that," explaining causa .
futura: sc. esse .
non . . . modo: "not only": "not only to think this is nefas , but even to utter it."

quid: "to what extent?" refert: "differ [from]," with ablative; the usage is later Latin. vaticinio: "prophecy, incantation." Tiresiae: genitive < Tiresias , the blind Theban soothsayer. The quotation is from Horace, Sermones 2.5.59, a parody of Tiresias's conversation with Ulysses in the underworld.
praestiterit: "shall have excelled," with ablative of comparison. uti homines: "as men [do]." incerta: sc. esse .
incerti: partitive genitive with nihil . praescierit: future perfect < praescio .
Quo: sc. argumento . occasus: "fall, ruination."
ad alterutrum: i.e., to goodness or to wickedness.

quicquam: "at all"; adverbial. fuerint: potential subjunctive. quoque = quo + -que , "and, than which . . ." fit: in a hypothetical discussion you would expect fiat , but the indicative renders the imagined state more vivid.
sperandi . . . deprecandi: "hoping [for] . . . praying away."

vicem: "recompense, reciprocation." gratiae: The only occurrence in the Consolatio of this word in a sense approaching its Christian use. qui: antecedent is commercium , but gender is from modus . illique inaccessae luci: "and to that unapproachable light"; dative with coniungi . Prayer brings God and man together in a limited way before the final union of the afterlife. prius . . . quam = priusquam . impetrent: sc. lucem .
Quae: i.e., hope and prayer. recepta futurorum necessitate: ablative absolute. virium: partitive genitive (< vires ) with nihil .
paulo ante: 4M6.43 fatiscere: figurative: "become exhausted, drained of strength."

div.head: Metrum 3:
div.p: B. puts his perplexity into verse.
Meter: Anapestic dimeter with diaeresis. The last verse is a monometer ( - u u - - ).
veris . . . duobus: "two truths."
carptim: "in parts, piecemeal."
No diaeresis between halves of verse in this line.
oppressi luminis igne: for oppressi ignis lumine (transferred epithet: here for metrical reasons). The light of the mind is caecis obruta membris , hence does not shine.
flagrat: sc. mens . notas: "signs, indicators."
Scitne: "Does [the mind] know [already] . . . ?"
nota: < nosco .
caeca: nominative singular.
nescita: accusative plural, the opposite of nota (line 14).
mentem . . . altam: i.e., the divine mind. summam et singula: "the whole and its parts."
condita: sc. mens humana (from line 8). membrorum: sc. corporis (see note on line 9).
in totum: "completely." sui: see on 1P2.6.
neutro . . . habitu: "in neither condition"; specified in 26-27.
alte visa: "things seen on high."
servatis: "to the [parts] retained (i.e., remembered)." Compare the discussion of memory's role in 3M11.

div.head: Prosa 4:
div.p: P. begins to explain providence and freedom of the will with an analysis of kinds of cognition.

M.que = Marcoque (Cicero is meant); a dative of agent with the participle agitata . distribuit: "categorized" ( De Divinatione 2.8ff, but the reference is not particularly apt). vestrum: partitive genitive with ullo .
ammoveri: "approach," in a middle sense. nihil ambigui: "nothing ambiguous, no ambiguity."
moveris: here, "are troubled." expendero: < expendo , "assess accurately."
illam solventium rationem: "this method of those who resolve [the problem]"; cf. 5P3.7.
futurorum necessitatis: "of the necessity of future events." non evenire non possunt: both negatives must be translated.
praenotio: "foreknowledge." adicit: < adicio ; here, "adds, contributes." paulo ante: 5P3.9. quid est quod: "why is it that . . . ?" voluntarii: "resulting from acts of the will," with exitus .
positionis gratia: "for the sake of argument"; positio here is a logical term (compare English "posit"). statuamus: "let us assume."
quantum . . . attinet: "as much as pertains to this," i.e., "as for that."
esse . . . iniungere: sc. praescientiam as subject.
necessario: adverb, "necessarily." ea esse ventura: accusative/infinitive after signum est .
quid sit: "what is."
nihil non ex necessitate contingere: i.e., that everything does occur by necessity. haec . . . illa: sc. necessitas . . . praenotio .
The same insistence on avoiding arguments drawn from without characterized the central exposition of Book 3 (cf. 3P12.35). subnixam: "relying, resting on," with ablative.
habuisse: supply ea (from beginning of sentence) as subject accusative.

fiunt: "are being done, are happening." Fio is used in this sense throughout secs. 15-20. ut ea: "such as those . . ." quadrigis: "four-horse chariots." aurigae: "charioteers"; subject of spectantur . atque . . . cetera: "and other [examples] of this sort."
illud: object of dicturum . nullum: "no one," subject accusative of dicturum (classical usage would dictate neminem ).
nihil . . . necessitatis: "no necessity."
videntur: subject must be supplied from earum rerum in the preceding sentence.
incerti . . . exitus: genitive singular. id esse caliginem: sc. patet or apparet . aliter . . . ac: "otherwise than." arbitrari: "to think," with force of noun, "thinking"; subject of esse .
ipsorum: antecedent in quae sciuntur .
sui = suam . cognoscentium: "of the ones doing the knowing."

visus . . . tactus: nominative, "vision . . . touch." eminus: "out of reach." iactis radiis: "rays darted forth"; sc. oculorum ; ancient physiologists explained sight as the result of rays that shot out from the eyes to the object seen. cohaerens: "clinging to," with dative. circa ipsum motus ambitum: "having moved around its perimeter." For the voice of motus see on ammoveri (5P4.2).

sensus: the physical sense of sight. imaginatio: the mental power to create images of things unseen. ratio: the power to reason from particulars to universals. intellegentia: the understanding of the unity that underlies the multiplicity of forms.
in subiecta materia: "in matter subject [to the figura imposed on it]."
universali consideratione: i.e., "by consideration or comparison with that which is universal" (cf. Platonic ideas/forms; in sec. 32 infra, universales species ).
exsistit = est , as often in later Latin. supergressa: < supergredior , "pass beyond"; sc. intellegentia . universitatis: here, "the universe."
amplectitur: "embraces," here: "includes."
aliquid: "at all"; adverbial accusative. concepta forma: ablative absolute (cf. forma in sec. 30). quae: antecedent is cuncta . nulli alii: dative; i.e., not to sensus , imaginatio , or ratio .
cognoscit: subject understood is intellegentia . ut ita dicam: "so to speak."
quid universale: "something universal"; one of the forms.
Haec: i.e., ratio . universale: here, "the universal form." The definition of man is a sample of ratio 's way of knowing; cf. 1P6.15 for a similar definition.
cum: "although." nullus = nemo . illa: sc. ratio .
collustrat: "surveys." imaginaria ratione: "by the method of imaginatio ."
cuncta: subject of utantur . sua: modifies facultate , contrasts with eorum .
iniuria: "wrongly"; adverbial.

div.head: Metrum 4:
div.p: P. asserts the powers of the mind against Stoic doctrines of the mind as tabula rasa .
Meter: Glyconic.
Porticus: "The Porch," i.e., the Stoa of Athens, where under Zeno was born the Stoicism that is attacked in these lines.
corporibus: second syllable scanned long here. extimis: "outermost," i.e., alien from the spirit within.
ut: "just as." quondam: "sometimes."
The image is from the stylus-marked wax tablet, the everyday writing material of antiquity. aequore: any smooth, level surface; ablative of place where with figere (line 9).
propriis . . . motibus: "by its own activity."
notis: here, the impressions made on the senses.
cassas: "empty, insubstantial." in speculi vicem: "in the manner of a mirror."
singula . . . cognita . . . divisa: accusative plural.
Compare the description of P. in 1P1.2.
sese referens sibi: "bringing itself back to itself," after considering all things lofty and deep.
efficiens . . . causa: technical term of logic: "efficient cause." efficiens magis = efficientior .
longe: with potentior , for emphasis.
quae: sc. causa . materiae modo: "in the manner of matter."
passio: "suffering, experience" (cf. patitur ); some bodily experience (at least sensory impression) precedes mental activity.
species: object of both vocans and applicat , attracted into the relative clause.
notis . . . exteris: " notae [coming from] outside."
introrsum: adverb with reconditis .

div.head: Prosa 5:
div.p: P. continues to distinguish human from divine modes of understanding.

corporibus: "bodies," the material objects accessible to the senses; in corporibus sentiendis = cum corpora sentiantur . forinsecus: "outwardly." obiectae qualitates: "qualities that present themselves"; subject of afficiant . insignitur: "is marked, characterized." ea, quae: Chaucer's gloss in his translation at this point suggests "as God or his angels". absoluta: "freed from." expediunt: "accomplish, unfold, carry out."
cognitiones: "[modes of] knowledge"; i.e., sensus , imaginatio , ratio , intellegentia .
quaeque alia = et alia quae . imaginatio: sc. cessit . iam: "already (as we move up the hierarchy of creatures)."
tantum: "only" (for variation, B. uses the adjective sola in the next clause). proprium: sc. subiectum ; i.e., that which is subject specially and particularly to it.
ratiocinationi: i.e., the activity of ratio . dicentes: with sensus imaginatioque .

This section gives the argument made by sensus and imaginatio (hence the accusative/infinitive construction) against ratio and its claims ( ratio 's response is in section 7). sibi notum sit: an impersonal verbal construction ( sibi = rationi ) introducing accusative/infinitive, plura . . . subiecta .

si ratio . . . esse credendum: protasis of a condition; for the apodosis we must wait for the clause beginning with nonne . se quidem: answered by illa vero two lines later. illa: sensus et imaginatio . firmiori . . . iudicio: dative with credendum esse ("one must believe"). in . . . lite: "in a quarrel of this sort."
quod: "that." futura: object of intueri . ut: "in the way that, as."
disseris: 5P3.19. certo: adverb; modifying praesciri .
quam: relative pronoun, antecedent praescientia .
uti: "just as," answered by ita . sicuti: answered by sic .

erigamur: passive form for intransitive action: "let us lift ourselves up." This ascent is possible only in light of the corollarium at 3P10.22. id . . . est: "i.e." quonam . . . videat . . . praenotio: indirect question, governed by videbit . neque = et non , continuing the indirect question.

div.head: Metrum 5:
div.p: The position of mankind is between earth and heaven.

Meter: Archilochean (dactylic tetrameter plus an ithyphallic - u - u - - , with diaeresis). "The ithyphallic . . . is the second half of a catalectic iambic trimeter taken after the caesura after the second anceps." (See Rosenmeyer, Ostwald, Halporn, The Meters of Greek and Latin Poetry, 89.)
extento . . . corpore: ablative of description. verrunt: "sweep."
vi pectoris incitata: "urged along by strength of chest"; B. is describing the motive power of reptiles.
sunt quibus: "there are those for whom"; a second category. levitas: subject of sit (understood), verberet , enatet .
liquido . . . volatu: "in smooth, easy flight." enatet: "swims along through," metaphorically.
haec: a third group of animals. solo: < solum , "ground."
transmittere vel subire: "to go across or enter under."
Quae . . . omnia: sc. animalia ; quae is connecting relative.
prona . . . facies: "downcast visage"; cf. B.'s posture earlier (1P1.14).
cacumen: for caput ; cf. 1P1.2.
levis: modifies gens . recto = erecto .
Haec . . . figura: i.e., mankind's erect posture. male: with words having a bad sense, "very much"; cf. the English "badly."
exseris: "stretch forth" (an inquisitive posture).
feras: iussive subjunctive. pessum: adverb, "all the way down."
corpore levius levato: ablative of comparison.

div.head: Prosa 6:
div.p: Divine knowledge sees from the vantage point of eternity and thus knows all that has happened and will happen without impeding freedom of human voluntary action.
paulo ante: 5P4.24.
Deum . . . esse: accusative/infinitive, subject of est .
ex collatione: "from comparison."
crastinum . . . hesternum: sc. spatium ; "tomorrow's . . . yesterday's."
Aristoteles: De Caelo 283b.26ff.
licet: take closely with infinitae . futura . . . transacta: "things to come . . . things past."

pariter: "equally, all at once." idque . . . assistere . . . habere: accusative/infinitive after necesse est . assistere: "to be present/at hand." infinitatem . . . habere: Though time is full of motion and boundless, it is nonetheless seen from the point of view of eternity as though it were all simultaneously present.

visum: sc. esse . Platoni: B. has in mind an interpretation current in his time of passages such as Statesman 270A, Timaeus 28B. On the significance of the issue for interpretation of the Consolatio , cf. Gruber.
totam . . . praesentiam: object of complexum esse .
proprietate: "by [i.e., as] a property."

praesentarium statum: i.e., a condition in which all things are perceived as if present, with no past or future. effingere: "make an image, imitate." aliquatenus: "to some extent." quibuscumque contigerit: "to whatever things it touches." id: i.e., ut esse videantur , "that they seem to exist."
eundo: gerund < eo, ire .
Platonem: cf. Timaeus 37D. The formal distinction between eternity and perpetuity really originated among Greek Neoplatonists, perhaps with Proclus.
supergressa: modifying scientia ; see on 5P4.30. quasi iam gerantur: "as if they [sc. omnia ] were now (i.e., all in present time) being carried on."
dinoscit: sc. deus . instantiae: "present moment."
praevidentia . . . providentia: plays on the meanings of the prefixes prae - (before in time) and pro - (before in space). quod: "because." porro a rebus infimis: "far from the lowliest of things."
cum ne homines . . . videant: as argued 5P4.4ff.
praesentis: participle as substantive, "the present." temporario: "temporal," the opposite of eternal.
olim: "at some time."
dispiciens: "seeing clearly." praesentium . . . futurarum: sc. rerum . ad condicionem . . . temporis: "with respect to their status in time"; i.e., "from a temporal point of view."
exstaturum: < exsto , "exist." quod idem: antecedent is quid . non nesciat: the negatives cancel each other out.
rem: here, "proposition." divini speculator: "one who contemplates the divine."
idem futurum: "the same future [event]."
condicionis: "condition," in the grammatical/logical sense.
simplicem: sc. necessitatem .
voluntate: ablative of cause with gradientem .
non desinunt: "do not leave off from."
Quid . . . refert: "What does it matter?" The answer is Hoc scilicet , specified by the following noun clause. instar: "likeness," with the genitive; subject of eveniet .
paulo ante: 5P6.22. unum: sc. sol oriens . alterum: sc. gradiens homo .
sicuti . . . singulare: cf. 5P5.5ff. ad se ipsa: plural, though the antecedent ( omne ) is singular.
propositum: "intention."
id te posse: indirect statement governed by intuetur . an facias quove convertas: indirect questions governed by intuetur .
meane = mea + ne . illa: sc. scientia divina . noscendi vices: "changing forms of knowing."
This editor's punctuation makes the last lines of the Consolatio spoken by B.; most editors disagree. Some even give minime to P. praevenit: "forestalls, heads off."
Quam . . . praesentiam: "and this presentness," i.e., this ability to experience things as if they were all present simultaneously.
paulo ante: 5P3.15.
praesentaria: ablative. posterioribus: "to things [logically] later in order."
intemerata: "unspoiled."
desuper: adverb; with speculator (which has an implied verbal force). concurrit: "concurs, corresponds."
Aversamini: imperative < aversor , "turn aside." necessitas: the Consolatio ends with a piece of word-play.
